docs.abstract: Women sometimes redo their appearance after a bout with cancer; changing one's hair color, figure or wardrobe can be a way of regaining control of one's life; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: LAST year, when Greta Carl, a 55-year-old lawyer in Chicago, was told by her doctor that she was nearly 100 percent clean from her bout with ovarian cancer, she grew her hair to her shoulders for the first time in her life, and dyed her gray hair Goldilocks blond. ''I love it,'' she said. ''It's flattering. It's sexier. It's a way of shouting, 'Hey, I'm alive!' '' For Ms. Carl, releasing her inner blonde was an act of fearlessness. ''I've always been the kind of person who wouldn't want to be noticed,'' she said. Chemotherapy had left her bald. ''I had a bloated, fat face, no eyebrows and eyelashes, and people would not recognize me,'' she recalled. ''So, I bought my Shirley MacLaine wig, short and red. That way I had an excuse for how my appearance had changed.''
